intro: Pseudomertensia echioides, commonly known as the ghost flower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, white, umbrella-shaped inflorescences that bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in moist, shady environments and is often found in woodlands and along stream banks. Its unique appearance and habitat make it a distinctive and ecologically important species in its native range.
